data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="sizeLarge layoutHorizontal css-1a1lp8y" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-bsn42l"><img alt="Jackson Palmer, creator of Dogecoin, in San Francisco on Friday. He was an early fan of cryptocurrency, but is now one of the loudest voices warning of a crash in the market." class="css-rq4mmj" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/09/16/business/16roose-sub/16roose-sub-articleInline.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/09/16/business/16roose-sub/16roose-sub-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/09/16/business/16roose-sub/16roose-sub-jumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/09/16/business/16roose-sub/16roose-sub-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" decoding="async" width="190" height="127"/></div><figcaption class="css-13o4bnb e1maroi60"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Jackson Palmer, creator of Dogecoin, in San Francisco on Friday. He was an early fan of cryptocurrency, but is now one of the loudest voices warning of a crash in the market.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span>Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div data-testid="byline-timestamp" class="css-xt80pu eakwutd0"><div class="css-sklrp3"><div class="css-1e2jphy epjyd6m1"><div class="css-233int epjyd6m0"><p class="css-aknsld e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/kevin-roose" class="css-mrorfa e1jsehar0">Kevin Roose</a></span></p></div></div><ul class="css-1u1psjv epjyd6m3"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m2"><time class="css-129k401 e16638kd0" dateTime="2017-09-15T17:01:43-04:00">Sept. 15, 2017</time></li></ul></div></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Jackson Palmer no longer thinks it’s funny to imitate <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/10/business/dogecoin-elon-musk.html" title="">Doge</a>, the internet meme about a Shiba Inu dog whose awe-struck expressions and garbled syntax (e.g. “Wow. So pizza. Much delicious.”) made him a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.theverge.com/2013/12/31/5248762/doge-meme-rescue-dog-wow" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">viral sensation</a> several years ago.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But if he did, he might channel Doge to offer a few cautionary words for investors who are falling for cryptocurrency start-ups, Silicon Valley’s latest moneymaking craze:<br/></p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Very bubble. Much scam. So avoid.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Mr. Palmer, the creator of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/05/business/dogecoin-continues-its-scarcely-believable-surge.html" title="">Dogecoin</a>, was an early fan of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/15/style/dogecoin-cryptocurrency-investment.html" title="">cryptocurrency</a>, a form of encrypted digital money that is traded from person to person. He saw investors talking about Bitcoin, the oldest and best-known cryptocurrency, and wanted to find a way to poke fun at the hype surrounding the emerging technology.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">So in 2013, he built his own cryptocurrency, a satirical mash-up that combined Bitcoin with the Doge meme he’d seen on social media. Mr. Palmer hoped to use Dogecoin to show the absurdity of wagering huge sums of money on unstable ventures.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-cfo9c3"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But investors didn’t get the joke and bought Dogecoin anyway, bringing its <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://dogecoin.com/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">market value</a> as high as $400 million. Along the way, the currency became a magnet for greed and attracted a group of scammers and hackers who defrauded investors, hyped fake products, and left many of the currency’s original backers empty-handed.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Today, Mr. Palmer, 30, is one of the loudest voices warning that a similar fate might soon befall the entire cryptocurrency industry.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“What’s happening to crypto now is what happened to Dogecoin,” Mr. Palmer told me in a recent interview. “I’m worried that this time, it’s on a much grander scale.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Already, there are signs of trouble on the horizon. This week, after Chinese authorities <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/14/business/china-bitcoin-exchange.html?mcubz=1" title="">announced</a> a crackdown on virtual currencies, the value of Bitcoin briefly tumbled 30 percent before partially recovering. The value of Dogecoin fell more than 50 percent last week. Its market value by midday Friday was about $100 million.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But there remains no bigger mania among tech investors than cryptocurrency, which some see as an eventual replacement for traditional, government-issued money. Even with the recent declines, the price of Bitcoin has more than tripled this year; another cryptocurrency, Ethereum, has gained more than 2,300 percent. The success of these currencies has minted a new class of “crypto-millionaires” and spawned hundreds of other digital currencies, called altcoins. In addition, it has given rise to an entire category of start-ups that take advantage of cryptocurrency’s public ledger system, known as the blockchain.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Many cryptocurrency start-ups have raised money through an <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/23/business/dealbook/coin-digital-currency.html?mcubz=1" title="">initial coin offering</a>, or I.C.O., a type of fund-raising campaign in which investors buy into a new venture using Bitcoin or another cryptocurrency and receive virtual “tokens” instead of stock or voting rights in the company. These tokens grant investors access to a product or service that will be built with the money raised in the I.C.O., such as cloud data storage or access to a new social network.</p><div id="NYT_MAIN_CONTENT_1_REGION" class="css-9tf9ac" data-testid="region"></div><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">(If you’re having trouble picturing it: Imagine that a friend is building a casino and asks you to invest. In exchange, you get chips that can be used at the casino’s tables once it’s finished. Now imagine that the value of the chips isn’t fixed, and will instead fluctuate depending on the popularity of the casino, the number of other gamblers and the regulatory environment for casinos. Oh, and instead of a friend, imagine it’s a stranger on the internet who might be using a fake name, who might not actually know how to build a casino, and whom you probably can’t sue for fraud if he steals your money and uses it to buy a Porsche instead. That’s an I.C.O.)</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Despite the obvious risks of these ventures, investor appetite has been ravenous. A group of Bay Area programmers this year used an I.C.O. to raise $35 million for their project, an anonymous web browser called Brave, in less than 30 seconds. There have been 140 coin offerings in 2017 that have raised a total of $2.1 billion from investors, according to Coinschedule, a website that tracks the activity.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">I.C.O. fever has even infected celebrities. This month, the actress Paris Hilton <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/ParisHilton/status/904456098035286016" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">tweeted</a> that she was “looking forward to participating” in the initial coin offering of LydianCoin, a cryptocurrency project associated with the digital advertising company Gravity4. The boxing star Floyd Mayweather and the rapper the Game have also endorsed coin offerings.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div class="css-cfo9c3"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Unlike traditional stock offerings, which are carefully supervised and planned months or years in advance, I.C.O.s are largely unregulated in the United States, although that could soon change. The Securities and Exchange Commission <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.investor.gov/additional-resources/news-alerts/alerts-bulletins/investor-alert-public-companies-making-ico-related" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">warned investors</a> this year about the growing number of coin offerings, saying that “fraudsters often try to use the lure of new and emerging technologies to convince potential victims to invest their money in scams.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Mr. Palmer predicts that while some I.C.O.s may finance the creation of new and exciting enterprises, many will go up in smoke. He sees echoes of the first dot-com boom, when investors poured money into new and risky ventures only to get burned when the market came to its senses.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“People are treating cryptocurrency now like penny stocks,” he said. “It’s become a securities market.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Other high-profile skeptics have sounded the alarm about a potential crash in the crypto market, including Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, who <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/12/jpmorgan-ceo-jamie-dimon-raises-flag-on-trading-revenue-sees-20-percent-fall-for-the-third-quarter.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">last week called Bitcoin a “fraud,”</a> and compared the current digital money craze to the 17th-century Dutch tulip bubble. And even true cryptocurrency believers have started to worry that I.C.O. mania won’t end well.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“It’s a ticking time bomb,” Charles Hoskinson, one of the developers of the cryptocurrency Ethereum, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-18/ethereum-co-founder-says-crypto-coin-market-is-ticking-time-bomb" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">told Bloomberg</a> in July.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">When Mr. Palmer’s interest in digital money began, just four years ago, cryptocurrency was the sole province of math geeks and early adopters.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“It was fun, nobody took it seriously,” he recalled. “People threw it around like change because it wasn’t worth anything.”</p><section role="complementary" class="css-14gh6yt" aria-label="A Guide to Cryptocurrency"><h2 class="css-ba3d02">A Guide to Cryptocurrency</h2><hr/><div id="storyline-context-container" aria-live="polite" aria-atomic="true"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Card 1 of 7</span><div data-scrolled-index="0" class="swiper css-1goft0b"><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="false"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>A glossary.<!-- --> </strong><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/25/technology/cryptocurrency-mainstream.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Cryptocurrencies</a> have gone from a curiosity to a viable investment, making them almost impossible to ignore. If you are struggling with the terminology, let us help:</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Bitcoin.<!-- --> </strong><span>A <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/01/technology/what-is-bitcoin-price.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Bitcoin</a> is a digital token that can be sent electronically from one user to another, anywhere in the world. Bitcoin is also the name of the payment network on which this form of digital currency is stored and moved.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Blockchain.<!-- --> </strong><span>A <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/27/business/dealbook/blockchains-guide-information.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">blockchain</a> is a database maintained communally, that <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/06/27/business/dealbook/blockchain-currencies.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">reliably stores digital information</a>. The original blockchain was the database on which all Bitcoin transactions were stored, but non-currency-based companies and governments are also trying to use blockchain technology to store their data.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Cryptocurrencies.<!-- --> </strong><span>Since Bitcoin was <a href="https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/interactive/technology/bitcoin-timeline.html">first conceived in 2008</a>, thousands of other virtual currencies, known as <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/25/business/dealbook/bitcoin-cash-split.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">cryptocurrencies</a>, have been developed. Among them are <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/01/technology/what-is-ethereum.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Ether</a>, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/15/style/dogecoin-cryptocurrency-investment.html?searchResultPosition=2&action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Dogecoin</a> and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/21/technology/bitcoin-bitfinex-tether.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Tether</a>.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Coinbase.<!-- --> </strong><span>The first major cryptocurrency company to list its shares on a U.S. stock exchange, Coinbase is a platform that allows people and companies <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/14/business/how-did-coinbase-stock-do.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">to buy and sell various digital currencies</a>, including Bitcoin, for a transaction fee.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Crypto finance.<!-- --> </strong><span>The development of cryptocurrencies spawned a parallel universe of alternative financial services, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/05/us/politics/cryptocurrency-explainer.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">known as Decentralized Finance, or DeFi</a>, allowing crypto businesses to move into traditional banking territory, including lending and borrowing.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>NFTs.<!-- --> </strong><span>A “nonfungible token,” or NFT, is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/11/arts/design/what-is-an-nft.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">an asset verified using blockchain technology</a>, in which a network of computers records transactions and gives buyers proof of authenticity and ownership. NFTs make <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/01/arts/design/banksy-nft-loic-gouzer-particle.html?searchResultPosition=11&action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">digital artworks</a> unique, and therefore sellable.</span></p></div></div></div></div><div class="css-8r08w0"><ul class="css-1dxpste"><li class="css-cromoy" data-active="true"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li></ul><nav aria-controls="storyline-context-container" class="css-9yx14y"><span class="arrow-left css-bfw7ir" role="button" aria-label="Previous card" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="-1"></span><span class="arrow-right css-e7hrc3" role="button" aria-label="Next card" aria-disabled="false" tabindex="0"></span></nav></div></section><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Unlike Bitcoin, whose early adopters often used it to buy drugs, weapons, or other illicit goods on the dark web, Dogecoin attracted a crowd of earnest do-gooders at first. They even set up a philanthropic arm, called the Dogecoin Foundation, and used it to raise thousands of dollars for projects, including sponsoring service dogs for autistic children and drilling water wells in Kenya. (Their generosity extended to quirkier projects; when Dogecoin fans heard that Jamaica’s two-man bobsled team had qualified for the Winter Olympics in Sochi but lacked the money to get to Russia, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2014/01/22/265060754/wow-dogecoin-other-donors-send-jamaican-bobsled-team-to-sochi" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">they pitched in</a> $30,000 to fund the trip.)</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">As the price of Bitcoin climbed, investors got interested in other cryptocurrencies. With no explanation, the price of Dogecoin doubled, then tripled. Two months after it was introduced, Mr. Palmer’s joke was worth $50 million, and some early Dogecoin adopters, who called themselves “shibes,” were sitting on lucrative stockpiles.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The success of Dogecoin attracted unsavory characters. One scammer raised $750,000 from Dogecoin supporters for a cryptocurrency start-up that never materialized. A hacker broke into Dogewallet, a website where users stored their coins, and stole thousands of dollars worth of the currency. Soon, the Dogecoin Reddit forum was full of angry scam victims and get-rich-quick schemers, and the once tight-knit Dogecoin community started to disintegrate.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“We tried to do everything right,” said Ben Doernberg, a former board member of the Dogecoin Foundation. “But when you have a situation where people stand to put in a dollar and take out a thousand dollars, people lose their minds.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Mr. Palmer, a laid-back Australian who works as a product manager in the Bay Area and describes himself as “socialist leaning,” was disturbed by the commercialization of his joke currency. He had never collected Dogecoin for himself, and had resisted efforts to cash in on the currency’s success, even turning down a $500,000 investment offer from an Australian venture capital firm.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">In 2015, he announced he was leaving Dogecoin behind, telling <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.coindesk.com/dogecoin-founder-bitcoin-toxic/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">an interviewer</a> that the cryptocurrency market “increasingly feels like a bunch of white libertarian bros sitting around hoping to get rich and coming up with half-baked, buzzword-filled business ideas.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">He recently began making a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/JacksonPalmer" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">series of YouTube videos</a> that explain tech topics to beginners, including how digital currencies work. His goal? To rekindle people’s excitement in the core blockchain technology, while tamping down some of the excessive hype.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“My mission in all of this is to help people better understand things, rather than just thinking about profit,” he said.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">It may be too late for that. Regulators in the United States have begun to scrutinize I.C.O.s, and China’s central bank went as far as issuing a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://techcrunch.com/2017/09/04/chinas-central-bank-has-banned-icos/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">temporary ban on new coin offerings</a>. But more dollars are still pouring into cryptocurrency ventures every day, as giddy investors ignore the warning signs and look to multiply their money.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Mr. Palmer worries that the coming reckoning in the cryptocurrency market — and it is coming, he says confidently — will deter people from using the technology for more legitimate projects.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“The bigger this bubble goes, the bigger negative connotation it’s going to have,” he said. “It’s going to be like the dot-com bust, but on a much more epic scale.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div></section><div></div><div></div><div></div><div></div><div><div id="bottom-wrapper" class="css-2fttua"><div id="bottom-slug" Now imagine that the value of the chips isn’t fixed, and will instead fluctuate depending on the popularity of the casino, the number of other gamblers and the regulatory environment for casinos. Oh, and instead of a friend, imagine it’s a stranger on the internet who might be using a fake name, who might not actually know how to build a casino, and whom you probably can’t sue for fraud if he steals your money and uses it to buy a Porsche instead. Bitcoin, whose early adopters often used it to buy drugs, weapons, or other illicit goods on the dark web, Dogecoin attracted a crowd of earnest do-gooders at first. They even set up a philanthropic arm, called the Dogecoin Foundation, and used it to raise thousands of dollars for projects, including sponsoring service dogs for autistic children and drilling water wells in Kenya. Two months after it was introduced, Mr. Palmer’s joke was worth $50 million, and some early Dogecoin adopters, who called themselves “shibes,” were sitting on lucrative stockpiles.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzE4ZDZjODc5LWJmMTItNTAwZi1hMTEyLTBkY2VjYjkxMmFlMg==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.49.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The success of Dogecoin attracted unsavory characters. One scammer raised $750,000 from Dogecoin supporters for a cryptocurrency start-up that never materialized. A hacker broke into Dogewallet, a website where users stored their coins, and stole thousands of dollars worth of the currency. usiness\u002F00roose\u002F00roose-thumbLarge.jpg","height":150,"width":150,"name":"thumbLarge","__typename":"ImageRendition"},"$LegacyCollection:TGVnYWN5Q29sbGVjdGlvbjpueXQ6Ly9sZWdhY3ljb2xsZWN0aW9uL2U3NDU0MmU1LTU4MTgtNTkyYS05ODkxLWQ5NTY1YzNjMTVhNA==.assets({\"first\":12}).edges.11":{"node":{"type":"id","generated":false,"id":"Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzY4MDk5NDlhLTAyZGEtNTRjZS04NTc1LTVjZjZiZTA1MWM3Mw==","typename":"Article"},"__typename":"AssetsEdge"},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzE4ZDZjODc5LWJmMTItNTAwZi1hMTEyLTBkY2VjYjkxMmFlMg==.storylines.0.storyline":{"uri":"nyt:\u002F\u002Fstoryline\u002F3ebf0054-7462-4612-9373-db6d88e097b3","displayName":"Crypto World Guide","hubAssets":[],"promotedLiveAssets":[],"__typename":"Storyline","experimentalJsonBlob":"{\"data\":[{\"version\":1,\"type\":\"experimentalJsonBlob\",\"data\":[{\"version\":1,\"type\":\"context\",\"data\":{\"title\":\"A Guide to Cryptocurrency\",\"items\":[{\"subtitle\":\"A glossary.\",\"text\":\"\u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F25\u002Ftechnology\u002Fcryptocurrency-mainstream.html\\\"\u003ECryptocurrencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E have gone from a curiosity to a viable investment, making them almost impossible to ignore. If you are struggling with the terminology, let us help:\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Bitcoin.\",\"text\":\"A \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F01\u002Ftechnology\u002Fwhat-is-bitcoin-price.html\\\"\u003EBitcoin\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a digital token that can be sent electronically from one user to another, anywhere in the world. Bitcoin is also the name of the payment network on which this form of digital currency is stored and moved.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Blockchain.\",\"text\":\"A \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2018\u002F06\u002F27\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fblockchains-guide-information.html\\\"\u003Eblockchain\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a database maintained communally, that \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2018\u002F06\u002F27\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fblockchain-currencies.html\\\"\u003Ereliably stores digital information\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The original blockchain was the database on which all Bitcoin transactions were stored, but non-currency-based companies and governments are also trying to use blockchain technology to store their data.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Cryptocurrencies.\",\"text\":\"Since Bitcoin was \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Farchive.nytimes.com\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbitcoin-timeline.html\\\"\u003Efirst conceived in 2008\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, thousands of other virtual currencies, known as \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F25\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fbitcoin-cash-split.html\\\"\u003Ecryptocurrencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, have been developed. Among them are \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F01\u002Ftechnology\u002Fwhat-is-ethereum.html\\\"\u003EEther\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F05\u002F15\u002Fstyle\u002Fdogecoin-cryptocurrency-investment.html?searchResultPosition=2\\\"\u003EDogecoin\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F11\u002F21\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbitcoin-bitfinex-tether.html\\\"\u003ETether\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Coinbase.\",\"text\":\"The first major cryptocurrency company to list its shares on a U.S. stock exchange, Coinbase is a platform that allows people and companies \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F14\u002Fbusiness\u002Fhow-did-coinbase-stock-do.html\\\"\u003Eto buy and sell various digital currencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, including Bitcoin, for a transaction fee.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Crypto finance.\",\"text\":\"The development of cryptocurrencies spawned a parallel universe of alternative financial services, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F09\u002F05\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcryptocurrency-explainer.html\\\"\u003Eknown as Decentralized Finance, or DeFi\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, allowing crypto businesses to move into traditional banking territory, including lending and borrowing.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"NFTs.\",\"text\":\"A “nonfungible token,” or NFT, is \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F11\u002Farts\u002Fdesign\u002Fwhat-is-an-nft.html\\\"\u003Ean asset verified using blockchain technology\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, in which a network of computers records transactions and gives buyers proof of authenticity and ownership. NFTs make \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F01\u002Farts\u002Fdesign\u002Fbanksy-nft-loic-gouzer-particle.html?searchResultPosition=11\\\"\u003Edigital artworks\u003C\u002Fa\u003E unique, and therefore sellable.\"}]}}]}]}","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Fstoryline\u002F3ebf0054-7462-4612-9373-db6d88e097b3","tone":"FEATURE","primaryAssets":[]},"Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzE4ZDZjODc5LWJmMTItNTAwZi1hMTEyLTBkY2VjYjkxMmFlMg==.storylines.0":{"storyline":{"type":"id","generated":true,"id":"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzE4ZDZjODc5LWJmMTItNTAwZi1hMTEyLTBkY2VjYjkxMmFlMg==.storylines.0.storyline","typename":"Storyline"},"__typename":"AssociatedStoryline","ruleName":"styln-crypto-business","testName":""},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzE4ZDZjODc5LWJmMTItNTAwZi1hMTEyLTBkY2VjYjkxMmFlMg==.storylines.1.storyline":{"uri":"nyt:\u002F\u002Fstoryline\u002Fef7f6ea6-8210-4c58-b782-bafc94f9136f","displayName":"Ransomware Attacks","hubAssets":[],"promotedLiveAssets":[],"__typename":"Storyline","experimentalJsonBlob":"{\"data\":[{\"version\":1,\"type\":\"experimentalJsonBlob\",\"data\":[{\"version\":1,\"type\":\"context\",\"data\":{\"title\":\"What to Know About Ransomware Attacks\",\"items\":[{\"subtitle\":\"What are ransomware attacks?\",\"text\":\"This form of cybercrime involves \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F29\u002Ftechnology\u002Fransomware-attacks-prevention.html\\\"\u003Ehackers breaking into computer networks\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and locking digital information until the victim pays for its release. Recent \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F05\u002F08\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcyberattack-colonial-pipeline.html\\\"\u003Ehigh-profile attacks\u003C\u002Fa\u003E have cast a spotlight on this rapidly expanding criminal industry, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F06\u002Fworld\u002Feurope\u002Fransomware-russia-bitcoin.html\\\"\u003Ewhich is based primarily in Russia\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Why are they becoming more common?\",\"text\":\"Experts say ransomware is \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2020\u002F02\u002F09\u002Ftechnology\u002Fransomware-attacks.html\\\"\u003Eattractive to criminals\u003C\u002Fa\u003E because the attacks take place mostly anonymously online, minimizing the chances of getting caught. The Treasury Department has estimated that Americans have paid $1.6 billion in ransoms since 2011.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Is there any connection to the rise of cryptocurrencies?\",\"text\":\"The criminal industry’s growth has been abetted by \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F09\u002F21\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Ftreasury-department-combating-ransomware-cryptocurrency.html\\\"\u003Ecryptocurrencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, like Bitcoin, which allow hackers to transact with victims anonymously, though experts see virtual currency exchanges as a weak point for ransomware gangs.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"What is being done about these attacks?\",\"text\":\"The U.S. military has taken \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F05\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fus-military-ransomware-cyber-command.html\\\"\u003Eoffensive measures\u003C\u002Fa\u003E against ransomware groups, and the Biden administration has taken \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F11\u002F08\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fjustice-dept-ransomware.html\\\"\u003Elegal\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F15\u002Fworld\u002Feurope\u002Fus-russia-sanctions.html\\\"\u003Eeconomic\u003C\u002Fa\u003E action. Recent attacks have propelled ransomware to the top of \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F10\u002F14\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fglobal-ransomware-meeting.html\\\"\u003EPresident Biden’s national security agenda\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Why is the government getting involved?\",\"text\":\"The attacks, which were mostly directed at individuals a few years ago, have dramatically escalated as hackers have begun \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F06\u002F03\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fransomware-cybersecurity-infrastructure.html\\\"\u003Etargeting critical infrastructure in the U.S.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, including a \u003Ca oembed.title: Is There a Cryptocurrency Bubble? Just Ask Doge. (Published 2017)
oembed.summary: Dogecoin was meant to poke fun at the hype around virtual currency. But now, its creator says, Dogecoin illustrates the risks.
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2017%2F09%2F15%2Fbusiness%2Fcryptocurrency-bubble-doge.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="Is There a Cryptocurrency Bubble? Just Ask Doge." style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>
oembed.thumbnail_credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times

readabilityObject.title: Is There a Cryptocurrency Bubble? Just Ask Doge.
readabilityObject.content:
The Shift

  • Sept. 15, 2017

Jackson Palmer no longer thinks it’s funny to imitate Doge, the internet meme about a Shiba Inu dog whose awe-struck expressions and garbled syntax (e.g. “Wow. So pizza. Much delicious.”) made him a viral sensation several years ago.

But if he did, he might channel Doge to offer a few cautionary words for investors who are falling for cryptocurrency start-ups, Silicon Valley’s latest moneymaking craze:

Very bubble. Much scam. So avoid.

Mr. Palmer, the creator of Dogecoin, was an early fan of cryptocurrency, a form of encrypted digital money that is traded from person to person. He saw investors talking about Bitcoin, the oldest and best-known cryptocurrency, and wanted to find a way to poke fun at the hype surrounding the emerging technology.

So in 2013, he built his own cryptocurrency, a satirical mash-up that combined Bitcoin with the Doge meme he’d seen on social media. Mr. Palmer hoped to use Dogecoin to show the absurdity of wagering huge sums of money on unstable ventures.

But investors didn’t get the joke and bought Dogecoin anyway, bringing its market value as high as $400 million. Along the way, the currency became a magnet for greed and attracted a group of scammers and hackers who defrauded investors, hyped fake products, and left many of the currency’s original backers empty-handed.

Today, Mr. Palmer, 30, is one of the loudest voices warning that a similar fate might soon befall the entire cryptocurrency industry.

“What’s happening to crypto now is what happened to Dogecoin,” Mr. Palmer told me in a recent interview. “I’m worried that this time, it’s on a much grander scale.”

Already, there are signs of trouble on the horizon. This week, after Chinese authorities announced a crackdown on virtual currencies, the value of Bitcoin briefly tumbled 30 percent before partially recovering. The value of Dogecoin fell more than 50 percent last week. Its market value by midday Friday was about $100 million.

But there remains no bigger mania among tech investors than cryptocurrency, which some see as an eventual replacement for traditional, government-issued money. Even with the recent declines, the price of Bitcoin has more than tripled this year; another cryptocurrency, Ethereum, has gained more than 2,300 percent. The success of these currencies has minted a new class of “crypto-millionaires” and spawned hundreds of other digital currencies, called altcoins. In addition, it has given rise to an entire category of start-ups that take advantage of cryptocurrency’s public ledger system, known as the blockchain.

Many cryptocurrency start-ups have raised money through an initial coin offering, or I.C.O., a type of fund-raising campaign in which investors buy into a new venture using Bitcoin or another cryptocurrency and receive virtual “tokens” instead of stock or voting rights in the company. These tokens grant investors access to a product or service that will be built with the money raised in the I.C.O., such as cloud data storage or access to a new social network.

(If you’re having trouble picturing it: Imagine that a friend is building a casino and asks you to invest. In exchange, you get chips that can be used at the casino’s tables once it’s finished. Now imagine that the value of the chips isn’t fixed, and will instead fluctuate depending on the popularity of the casino, the number of other gamblers and the regulatory environment for casinos. Oh, and instead of a friend, imagine it’s a stranger on the internet who might be using a fake name, who might not actually know how to build a casino, and whom you probably can’t sue for fraud if he steals your money and uses it to buy a Porsche instead. That’s an I.C.O.)

Despite the obvious risks of these ventures, investor appetite has been ravenous. A group of Bay Area programmers this year used an I.C.O. to raise $35 million for their project, an anonymous web browser called Brave, in less than 30 seconds. There have been 140 coin offerings in 2017 that have raised a total of $2.1 billion from investors, according to Coinschedule, a website that tracks the activity.

I.C.O. fever has even infected celebrities. This month, the actress Paris Hilton tweeted that she was “looking forward to participating” in the initial coin offering of LydianCoin, a cryptocurrency project associated with the digital advertising company Gravity4. The boxing star Floyd Mayweather and the rapper the Game have also endorsed coin offerings.

Unlike traditional stock offerings, which are carefully supervised and planned months or years in advance, I.C.O.s are largely unregulated in the United States, although that could soon change. The Securities and Exchange Commission warned investors this year about the growing number of coin offerings, saying that “fraudsters often try to use the lure of new and emerging technologies to convince potential victims to invest their money in scams.”

Mr. Palmer predicts that while some I.C.O.s may finance the creation of new and exciting enterprises, many will go up in smoke. He sees echoes of the first dot-com boom, when investors poured money into new and risky ventures only to get burned when the market came to its senses.

“People are treating cryptocurrency now like penny stocks,” he said. “It’s become a securities market.”

Other high-profile skeptics have sounded the alarm about a potential crash in the crypto market, including Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, who last week called Bitcoin a “fraud,” and compared the current digital money craze to the 17th-century Dutch tulip bubble. And even true cryptocurrency believers have started to worry that I.C.O. mania won’t end well.

“It’s a ticking time bomb,” Charles Hoskinson, one of the developers of the cryptocurrency Ethereum, told Bloomberg in July.

When Mr. Palmer’s interest in digital money began, just four years ago, cryptocurrency was the sole province of math geeks and early adopters.

“It was fun, nobody took it seriously,” he recalled. “People threw it around like change because it wasn’t worth anything.”

Unlike Bitcoin, whose early adopters often used it to buy drugs, weapons, or other illicit goods on the dark web, Dogecoin attracted a crowd of earnest do-gooders at first. They even set up a philanthropic arm, called the Dogecoin Foundation, and used it to raise thousands of dollars for projects, including sponsoring service dogs for autistic children and drilling water wells in Kenya. (Their generosity extended to quirkier projects; when Dogecoin fans heard that Jamaica’s two-man bobsled team had qualified for the Winter Olympics in Sochi but lacked the money to get to Russia, they pitched in $30,000 to fund the trip.)

As the price of Bitcoin climbed, investors got interested in other cryptocurrencies. With no explanation, the price of Dogecoin doubled, then tripled. Two months after it was introduced, Mr. Palmer’s joke was worth $50 million, and some early Dogecoin adopters, who called themselves “shibes,” were sitting on lucrative stockpiles.

The success of Dogecoin attracted unsavory characters. One scammer raised $750,000 from Dogecoin supporters for a cryptocurrency start-up that never materialized. A hacker broke into Dogewallet, a website where users stored their coins, and stole thousands of dollars worth of the currency. Soon, the Dogecoin Reddit forum was full of angry scam victims and get-rich-quick schemers, and the once tight-knit Dogecoin community started to disintegrate.

“We tried to do everything right,” said Ben Doernberg, a former board member of the Dogecoin Foundation. “But when you have a situation where people stand to put in a dollar and take out a thousand dollars, people lose their minds.”

Mr. Palmer, a laid-back Australian who works as a product manager in the Bay Area and describes himself as “socialist leaning,” was disturbed by the commercialization of his joke currency. He had never collected Dogecoin for himself, and had resisted efforts to cash in on the currency’s success, even turning down a $500,000 investment offer from an Australian venture capital firm.

In 2015, he announced he was leaving Dogecoin behind, telling an interviewer that the cryptocurrency market “increasingly feels like a bunch of white libertarian bros sitting around hoping to get rich and coming up with half-baked, buzzword-filled business ideas.”

He recently began making a series of YouTube videos that explain tech topics to beginners, including how digital currencies work. His goal? To rekindle people’s excitement in the core blockchain technology, while tamping down some of the excessive hype.

“My mission in all of this is to help people better understand things, rather than just thinking about profit,” he said.

It may be too late for that. Regulators in the United States have begun to scrutinize I.C.O.s, and China’s central bank went as far as issuing a temporary ban on new coin offerings. But more dollars are still pouring into cryptocurrency ventures every day, as giddy investors ignore the warning signs and look to multiply their money.

Mr. Palmer worries that the coming reckoning in the cryptocurrency market — and it is coming, he says confidently — will deter people from using the technology for more legitimate projects.

“The bigger this bubble goes, the bigger negative connotation it’s going to have,” he said. “It’s going to be like the dot-com bust, but on a much more epic scale.”

And even true cryptocurrency believers have started to worry that I.C.O. mania won’t end well.“It’s a ticking time bomb,” Charles Hoskinson, one of the developers of the cryptocurrency Ethereum, told Bloomberg in July.When Mr. Palmer’s interest in digital money began, just four years ago, cryptocurrency was the sole province of math geeks and early adopters.“It was fun, nobody took it seriously,” he recalled. “People threw it around like change because it wasn’t worth anything.”Unlike Bitcoin, whose early adopters often used it to buy drugs, weapons, or other illicit goods on the dark web, Dogecoin attracted a crowd of earnest do-gooders at first. They even set up a philanthropic arm, called the Dogecoin Foundation, and used it to raise thousands of dollars for projects, including sponsoring service dogs for autistic children and drilling water wells in Kenya. (Their generosity extended to quirkier projects; when Dogecoin fans heard that Jamaica’s two-man bobsled team had qualified for the Winter Olympics in Sochi but lacked the money to get to Russia, they pitched in $30,000 to fund the trip.)As the price of Bitcoin climbed, investors got interested in other cryptocurrencies. With no explanation, the price of Dogecoin doubled, then tripled. Two months after it was introduced, Mr. Palmer’s joke was worth $50 million, and some early Dogecoin adopters, who called themselves “shibes,” were sitting on lucrative stockpiles.The success of Dogecoin attracted unsavory characters. One scammer raised $750,000 from Dogecoin supporters for a cryptocurrency start-up that never materialized. A hacker broke into Dogewallet, a website where users stored their coins, and stole thousands of dollars worth of the currency. Soon, the Dogecoin Reddit forum was full of angry scam victims and get-rich-quick schemers, and the once tight-knit Dogecoin community started to disintegrate.“We tried to do everything right,” said Ben Doernberg, a former board member of the Dogecoin Foundation. “But when you have a situation where people stand to put in a dollar and take out a thousand dollars, people lose their minds.”Mr. Palmer, a laid-back Australian who works as a product manager in the Bay Area and describes himself as “socialist leaning,” was disturbed by the commercialization of his joke currency. He had never collected Dogecoin for himself, and had resisted efforts to cash in on the currency’s success, even turning down a $500,000 investment offer from an Australian venture capital firm.In 2015, he announced he was leaving Dogecoin behind, telling an interviewer that the cryptocurrency market “increasingly feels like a bunch of white libertarian bros sitting around hoping to get rich and coming up with half-baked, buzzword-filled business ideas.”He recently began making a series of YouTube videos that explain tech topics to beginners, including how digital currencies work. His goal? To rekindle people’s excitement in the core blockchain technology, while tamping down some of the excessive hype.“My mission in all of this is to help people better understand things, rather than just thinking about profit,” he said.It may be too late for that. Regulators in the United States have begun to scrutinize I.C.O.s, and China’s central bank went as far as issuing a temporary ban on new coin offerings. But more dollars are still pouring into cryptocurrency ventures every day, as giddy investors ignore the warning signs and look to multiply their money.Mr. Palmer worries that the coming reckoning in the cryptocurrency market — and it is coming, he says confidently — will deter people from using the technology for more legitimate projects.“The bigger this bubble goes, the bigger negative connotation it’s going to have,” he said. “It’s going to be like the dot-com bust, but on a much more epic scale.”
readabilityObject.excerpt: Dogecoin was meant to poke fun at the hype around virtual currency. But now, its creator says, Dogecoin illustrates the risks.
